questions.title: Longest Palindromic Substring
questions.introduction: Finding the longest palindromic substring is a classic string problem with multiple approaches: brute force, dynamic programming, and the elegant expand-around-center technique. A palindrome reads the same forwards and backwards.
questions.problemStatement:
Given a string s, return the longest palindromic substring in s.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s.length <= 1000
- s consist of only digits and English letters

examples.explanation: "bab" is a palindromic substring. "aba" is also a valid answer.

hints: Expand around center technique works well
Consider both odd-length and even-length palindromes
For each position, expand outward while characters match
Track the longest palindrome found
Dynamic programming: dp[i][j] = true if s[i..j] is palindrome
questions.timeComplexity: O(n²) for expand around center, O(n) for Manacher's algorithm
questions.spaceComplexity: O(1) for expand around center, O(n²) for DP

questions.title: Group Anagrams
questions.introduction: Grouping anagrams requires finding a way to identify strings that are anagrams of each other. Two strings are anagrams if they contain the same characters with the same frequencies. The key insight is finding a canonical representation for each group.
questions.problemStatement:
Given an array of strings strs, group the anagrams together. You can return the answer in any order.

An Anagram is a word or phrase formed by rearranging the letters of a different word or phrase, typically using all the original letters exactly once.

Constraints:
- 1 <= strs.length <= 10⁴
- 0 <= strs[i].length <= 100
- strs[i] consists of lowercase English letters
hints: Use sorted string as key for hash map
Alternatively, use character count as key
Character count key: "a2b1c1" for "abac"
All anagrams will have the same key
Group strings by their key in hash map
questions.timeComplexity: O(n × k log k) where k is max string length, or O(n × k) with counting

questions.title: Valid Anagram
questions.introduction: Checking if two strings are anagrams is a fundamental string problem. Two strings are anagrams if they contain the same characters with the same frequencies. This problem introduces character counting and hash map techniques.
questions.problemStatement:
Given two strings s and t, return true if t is an anagram of s, and false otherwise.

An Anagram is a word or phrase formed by rearranging the letters of a different word or phrase, typically using all the original letters exactly once.

Constraints:
- 1 <= s.length, t.length <= 5 × 10⁴
- s and t consist of lowercase English letters

examples.explanation: Both strings contain the same characters: a(3), n(1), g(1), r(1), m(1).

hints: If lengths are different, they can't be anagrams
Count character frequencies in both strings
Use an array of size 26 for lowercase letters
Alternatively, sort both strings and compare
For follow-up with Unicode, use a hash map
questions.timeComplexity: O(n) with counting, O(n log n) with sorting
questions.spaceComplexity: O(1) with counting (fixed 26 chars), O(n) with sorting

questions.title: Encode and Decode Strings
questions.introduction: Design an algorithm to encode a list of strings to a single string and decode it back to the original list. This problem requires handling edge cases like empty strings and strings containing special characters.
questions.problemStatement:
Design an algorithm to encode a list of strings to a single string. The encoded string is then decoded back to the original list of strings.

Implement encode and decode methods.

Constraints:
- 0 <= strs.length < 100
- 0 <= strs[i].length < 200
- strs[i] contains any possible characters out of 256 valid ASCII characters

examples.explanation: Encode to a single string, then decode back to original list.

hints: Use length prefix encoding: "5#Hello5#World"
Store length of each string followed by delimiter
This handles any character including the delimiter itself
Alternative: use escaping for special characters
Chunked transfer encoding is another approach
